introduction.p: There is no resistance in the ideal LC circuit in which even the resistance in teh wires is ignored. In reality, however, there is always some resistance in the circuit, for instance in the connecting wires and the materials of the inductor and the capacitor, which dissipate energy. Dissipation of energy from the circuit results in a decrease in current over time.

Oscillatory circuits also radiate electromagnetic waves and lose energy through radiation. We will not discuss the radiation of energy now, and assume that the loss by radiation is negligible compared to the loss due to resistance.
To understand the phenomenon of resistive damping better consider a circuit with a resistor R in series with a capacitor C and an inductor L as shown in .

sidebyside.p: Let the capacitor be charged initially with charges \pm Q_0 on the plates so that there is a voltage V_0 = Q_0/C at time t=0 between the capacitor plates.

introduction.p: When the switch is closed at t=0, current in the circuit will rise from zero to a maximum value, and then, depending on the values of R/2L vs 1/\sqrt{LC} , current will oscillate with decreasing amplitude or simply damp out as illustrated in below. Three types of behavior are seen.

ol.li: Underdamped Case. If R/2L \lt 1/\sqrt{LC}, then current in the circuit oscillates about the equilibrium value of zero, successively damping out each cycle.
Over-damped Case. If R/2L \gt 1/\sqrt{LC}, then current in the circuit does not oscillate; current just damps out to zero.
Critically Damped Case. If R/2L = 1/\sqrt{LC}, then current in the circuit does not oscillate; current just damps out to zero rather quickly.

introduction.p:
After solving Eq. for q, derived for the RLC-circuit below, we can get current by I=dq/dt. We find that current I(t) at time t with zero current at t=0 and charge \pm Q_0 at capacitor plates at t=0 for underdamped, overdamped, and critically-damped cases are given by the following expression.
I \amp = \begin{cases}
I_u = -Q_0\,e^{-\gamma\,t/2}\left( \dfrac{\gamma^2 + 4\omega_1^2}{4\omega_1} \right)\,\sin(\omega_1 t), \amp \omega_0 \gt \gamma/2,\\
I_o = -\alpha\,Q_0 \left( 1-\dfrac{\gamma^2}{4\alpha^2} \right) \,e^{-\gamma\,t/2}\sinh(\alpha t), \amp \omega_0 \lt \gamma/2,\\
I_c = -\dfrac{\gamma^2}{4} Q_0\,t\,e^{-\gamma\,t/2}, \amp \omega_0 = \gamma/2,
\end{cases} \amp
where I_u, I_o, and I_c refer to underdamped, overdamped, and critically-damped cases, and \sinh(x) is the sinh function whose explicit representation in terms of exponetials is
\sinh(x) = \dfrac{e^{x} - e^{-x}}{2}.
displays current in three types of damping. Critical damping id preferred over overdamping when you need to damp current quickly. Underdamping is important when studying oscillatory circuits, such as AC circuit and antennas.

figure.caption: Three types of damping illustrated. Parameters used for plot: (1) Underdamped R = 0.25\,\Omega, C=1\text{ F}, L = 1\text{ H}, (2) Overdamped R = 4\,\Omega, C=1\text{ F}, L = 1\text{ H}, (3) Critically damped R = 2\,\Omega, C=1\text{ F}, L = 1\text{ H}. The initial state: q(0) = Q_0 and I(0)=0.

subsection.title: Meaning of \gamma
subsection.p: To gain an understanding of the meaning of the damping parameter \gamma we look at underdamped oscillatory circuit. You will notice that the envelop of oscillations, i.e., the plot that has peaks or troughs as their points, falls off with time exponentially. The time for peak current to fall off to a fraction \dfrac{1}{e} of its max at some time is equal to 2/\gamma as illustrated in .

figure.caption: Envelops of an underdamped oscillations illustrate the time for current in the envelop to drop to 1/e of the initial value is 2/\gamma. Parameters used for plot: R = 0.25\,\Omega, C=1\text{ F}, L = 1\text{ H}. The initial state: q(0) = Q_0 and I(0)=0.

subsection.p:
The energy of the circuit is given by
U_\text{circuit} = \frac{1}{2}LI^2 + \frac{1}{2}CV_C^2.
This also oscillates and decays with time. Its envelop drops twice as fast as that shown in for the current. The time taken for energy envelop to drop by 1/e is equal to 1/\gamma. This is called time constant of the circuit.

subsection.title: Quality Factor Q of an Oscillator
subsection.p: Quality factor provides a standard way to talk about goodness of an oscillator. We denote Quality factor by Q. A simple measure of Quality of an oscillator would be to divide the average energy in a particular cycle by the energy lost in the cycle, so that the less the energy is lost in a cycle, the more persistent are the oscillations, and therefore, higher the Quality.

For technical reasons, we define Q factor by dividing the energy at the beginning of a cycle to the energy lost in \dfrac{1}{2\pi} of a cycle. The factor is not critical to the definition, but does give simpler formula when we apply this to a lightly damped oscillator. Suppose U(t) be the energy at time t, then we would compute Q by
Q = \dfrac{U(t)}{\left| \Delta U\left(\text{during }t\text{ to }t+ \dfrac{1}{\omega}\right) \right| };.

We get a simple formula for Q when oscillator is a good oscillator, for instance, when
\gamma \lt\lt \omega_0.
Under these conditions, the oscillator is called a lightly damped oscillator. For lightly damped case, energy envelop decreases exponentially and is given by
U(t) = U(0) e^{-\gamma t}.
It is then easy to work out energy lost during interval from t=t to t=t + \dfrac{1}{\omega} . The quality factor obtained by this calculation is
Q = \dfrac{\omega_0}{\gamma} = \dfrac{\sqrt{L}}{R\sqrt{C}}\ \ \ \ \ (\text{lightly damped oscillator})
Often, we use this formula, even when the underdamped oscillator is not lightly damped. In those cases, we just replace \omega in this formula by \omega_1, the actual angular frequency of the damped oscillator.
Q \sim \dfrac{\omega_1}{\gamma}\ \ \ \ \ (\text{underdamped oscillators})

Good mechanical oscillators such as tuning forks and guitar strings have Q values in the thousands. Laser cavities, which are electromagnetic wave oscillators, have much higher Q values, exceeding 10^7. Of course, the undamped oscillator has zero \gamma, and hence infinite Q. There is no Q for the critically damped and overdamped cases since they do not oscillate. You might say, their Q = 0.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Equation of Motion of RLC circuit
subsection.p: Faraday's flux rule around the circuit of gives rise to a second order differential equation for charge q(t) on the positive plate of the capacitor.

sidebyside.p:
Let \mathcal{E}_L, \mathcal{E}_R, and \mathcal{E}_C be EMF's around inductor, capacitor, and resistor, respectively. These are
\mathcal{E}_L = L\frac{dI}{dt},\ \ \mathcal{E}_R = IR,\ \ \mathcal{E}_C=\frac{1}{C}\,q,
with I = dq/dt.

subsection.p:
Going around the circuit loop, we get
\mathcal{E}_L + \mathcal{E}_R + \mathcal{E}_C =0.
In terms of q(t), the charge on positive plate of the capacior at instant t, this is
L\frac{d^2q}{dt^2} + R\frac{dq}{dt} + \frac{1}{C}\,q=0.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Solution of Equation of Motion of RLC circuit
subsection.p:
The solution of Eq. depends on relative values of R/L and 1/\sqrt{LC}. We denote these quantites by other symbols.
\omega_0 = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{LC}},\ \ \gamma = \dfrac{R}{L}.
With these changes Eq. becomes
\dfrac{d^2 q}{d t^2} + \gamma\, \dfrac{dq}{dt} + \omega_0^2\, q = 0.
Let us make the following substitution.
q(t) = e^{-\gamma\,t/2}\, x(t).
With this we get
\dfrac{d^2 x}{d t^2} + \left( \omega_0^2 - \gamma^2/4 \right) x = 0
The solution of this equation depends on \left( \omega_0^2 - \gamma^2/4 \right). If this constant is positive, we will have x as sine and cosine functions, if negative, the solution will be exponetial function, and if zero, x will be linear in t.
x \amp = \begin{cases} x_u = A\, \cos(\omega_1 t) + B\, \sin(\omega_1 t), \ \ \omega_1^2 = \omega_0^2 - \gamma^2/4 \gt 0,\\ x_o = A\, e^{\alpha t} + B\, e^{-\alpha t}, \ \ \alpha^2 = \gamma^2/4 - \omega_0^2 \gt 0,\\ x_c = A + B\,t, \ \ \omega_0 = \gamma/2 \end{cases} \amp
These three cases correspond to underdampig, overdamping, and critical damping respectively. Using these answers for x in Eq. gives us general solution. Note, in general solution we have two unknown constants A and B. We fix these constants from values of the initial charge q(0) and initial current I(0).

subsubsection.title: Underdamping Case with q(0)=Q_0 and I(0)=0
subsubsection.p: We now show how we can fix two undetermined constants in general solutions in Eq. . To be specific, we will work out the details for only the underdamped case.

We start with general solutions for q(t) and I(t).
\amp q(t) = e^{-\gamma\,t/2} \left( A\, \cos(\omega_1 t) + B\, \sin(\omega_1 t) \right), \amp I(t) = \dfrac{d q(t)}{dt} = -\dfrac{\gamma}{2} q(t) + \omega_1\,e^{-\gamma\,t/2} \left(- A\, \sin(\omega_1 t) + B\, \cos(\omega_1 t) \right).
Now, we set t=0 in them and use the initial values.
\amp Q_0 = A, \amp 0 = -\dfrac{\gamma}{2} Q_0 + \omega_1\, B.
Therefore we have the charge and current at arbitrary time
\amp q(t) = Q_0\,e^{-\gamma\,t/2} \left[\cos(\omega_1 t) + \dfrac{\gamma}{2\omega_1}\,\sin(\omega_1 t) \right], \amp I(t) = - Q_0\, \left( \omega_1 + \dfrac{\gamma^2}{4\omega_1} \right) \,e^{-\gamma\,t/2} \sin(\omega_1 t).
You can try to find solutions for other initial conditions and for the other two damping cases.

sidebyside.p: Consider RLC-circuit shown in and answer the following questions. (a) Find the natural frequency \omega_0 and the damping parameter \gamma, and determine if the circuit is under-damped, over-damped or critically damped.

statement.p: (b) At t=0, the charge on the capacitor was 15 \muC and the current in the circuit was zero, find the current in the circuit at an arbitrary time.
(c) What is the Q factor of the oscillator?
(d) (Calculus) How much energy is dissipated in first 2 seconds?

hint.p: (a) Use defining equations, (b) USe I_u, (c) Integrate power, I^2R.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) The natural frequency,
\omega_0 =\frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3\times10^{-3}\:\text{H}\times40\times10^{-6}\:\text{F}}} = 2887\ \text{sec}^{-1}
The damping parameter,
\gamma = \frac{R}{L} = \frac{10\ \Omega}{3\times 10^{-3}\:\text{H}} = 3334\ \text{sec}^{-1}.
Since \omega_0>\gamma/2, the circuit is under-damped.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) Putting in the numbers in I_u in Eq. , we obtain the following for the current in the circuit with t in sec. We will find the multiplying factor in the equation separately.
\omega_1 = \sqrt{ \omega_0^2 - \gamma^2/4 } = 2357\text{ sec}^{-1}.
This gives the following for the factor in the solution.
\text{factor}\amp = \left( \dfrac{\gamma^2 + 4\omega_1^2}{4\omega_1} \right) \amp = \left( \dfrac{3334^2 + 4\times 2357^2}{4 \times 2357} \right) = 3536\text{ sec}^{-1}.
Finally, using the formula for I_u we get
I \amp = -Q_0\,\left( \dfrac{\gamma^2 + 4\omega_1^2}{4\omega_1} \right)\, e^{-\gamma\,t/2}\,\sin(\omega_1 t), \amp = -15\,\mu\text{C}\times 3536\text{ s}^{-1}\, e^{-1667\,t}\,\sin(2357\, t), \amp = -53\text{ mA}\, e^{-1667\,t}\,\sin(2357\, t).

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) We will use \omega_1 for the Q factor.
Q\amp = \dfrac{\omega_1}{\gamma} = \dfrac{2357}{3334} = 0.7.
If you use \omega_0 in place of \omega_1, you will get a little larger value, here you will get 0.9. They are both order, O(1), i.e., the oscillator is not very good. If you get a Q of 10 or more, you will have a very good oscillator.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p:
(d) Integrate power deposited in duration (0, 2 sec) by inserting I(t) in part (b).
\text{Energy} = \int_0^2 I^2\: R dt = 2.8\:\mu\text{J}.

exercise.title: Practice with Determining Underdamped, Overdamped, or Critically Damped Circuits

statement.p: Determine if the circuits in are under-damped, over-damped, or critically damped.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: We will use damping parameter \beta = \gamma/2 rather than \gamma. It will simplify notation.

(a) The parameters of the given circuit are
\amp \beta = \dfrac{R}{2L} = \dfrac{1000\:\Omega}{2\times 1\:\text{H}} = 500\:\text{sec}^{-1}, \amp \omega_0 = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1\:\text{H}\times 4\times 10^{-6}\:\text{F}}} = 500\:\text{sec}^{-1}.
Since \omega_0 = \beta, this circuit is critically damped.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: We will use damping parameter \beta = \gamma/2 rather than \gamma. It will simplify notation.

(b) The parameters of the given circuit are
\amp \beta = \dfrac{R}{2L} = \dfrac{200\:\Omega}{2\times 1\:\text{H}} = 100\:\text{sec}^{-1}, \amp \omega_0 = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1\:\text{H}\times 4\times 10^{-6}\:\text{F}}} = 500\:\text{sec}^{-1}.
Since \omega_0 \gt \beta, this circuit is under-damped.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p: We will use damping parameter \beta = \gamma/2 rather than \gamma. It will simplify notation.

(c) The parameters of the given circuit are
\amp \beta = \dfrac{R}{2L} = \dfrac{1000\:\Omega}{2\times 1\:\text{H}} = 500\:\text{sec}^{-1}, \amp \omega_0 = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1\:\text{H}\times 4\times 10^{-12}\:\text{F}}} = 500,000\:\text{sec}^{-1}.
Since \omega_0 > \beta, this circuit is under-damped.

solution.title: (d)
solution.p: We will use damping parameter \beta = \gamma/2 rather than \gamma. It will simplify notation.

(d) The parameters of the given circuit are
\amp \beta = \dfrac{R}{2L} = \dfrac{300\:\Omega}{2\times 5\times 10^{-3}\:\text{H}} = 30,000\:\text{sec}^{-1}, \amp \omega_0 = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{5\times 10^{-3}\:\text{H}\times 2\times 10^{-6}\:\text{F}}} = 10,000\:\text{sec}^{-1}.
Since \omega_0 \lt \beta, this circuit is over-damped.
